‚öΩÔ∏è Manchester City 3 Burnley 1

Jan 31, 2024

Easily the worst that I have seen Burnley play this season. We contained Manchester City well for the first 15 minutes until Alvarez put city ahead. Alvarez extended the lead from a quickly taken free kick while Burnley switched off later in the first half, and Rodri wrapped up the goals for City from the restart after half time. Ameen Al Dakhil provided a consolation in injury time.

Despite the nature of two of the goals, the score is flattering. We looked off the pace, second to every ball, unable to keep the ball. The first 60-70 minutes were dreadful. The second half began to feel like a friendly. Until the substitutions.

The introduction of Anas Zaroury prompted 7 minutes of the Anas Zaroury song. Non-stop. After an interlude for the Manuel Benson song we returned to it! Wilson Obobert has been one of the high points of the winter, but was anonymous here, with Zaroury introducing much more threat down the left wing.

Connor Roberts brought some fight to the performance. Literally. How Ederson was not sent off for dragging him across the pitch in a headlock, I‚Äôve no idea. VAR, fucking pointless.

Fofana. Considering that he is self professed to be lazy and not like running, he ran with strength and power, but with finesse and ball control. Much more weight and fight up front. I‚Äôd hoped Obafemi might provide this, but he has gone out to Milwall on loan. He lined up the cross which resulted in the Burnley goal.

A final mention for Han Noah Massenho, who was given around 10 minutes for his premier league debut, and looked competent and not out of place.

I hope that we learn from that final spell, and bring the same fight and spirit to the remainder of the season.

If you enjoyed the article, don‚Äôt forget to say thanks by clicking the kudos button below, or sending me a message here, through mastodon, or email using the links below.

Up the clarets!

üèüÔ∏è Etihad Stadium

Jan 31, 2024

The Etihad Stadium in Manchester is the home of Manchester City FC. Originally built as an athletics stadium for the Commonwealth Games held in the city in 2002, the stadium was extended in 2014 to a capacity of 53,400, and is due to be expanded again to 60,000 over the next few years.

I have visited the stadium before, prior to the expansion, for a Foo Fighters gig in the early 2010s.

The match program is ¬£4, par in the Premier League.

The catering was pretty good really. ¬£11.50 bought me a huge Southern Fried Chicken and BBQ sauce wrap, a packet of crisps and a bovril. Slightly cheaper than the London clubs, but definitely not competing with the wonder that is the Wham Stadium.

Probably the most impressive bowl stadium that I‚Äôve visited, it really is like sitting in a theatre. The atmosphere is dreadful though and City have really overplayed the choreography. Reminding their fans of each of their songs about their team prior to kick off. It‚Äôs a really impressive structure, for a library.

üë®üèº‚Äçüíª Exercise: Use control flow and loops to solve a problem

Jan 30, 2024

My solution to the ‘Use control flow and loops to solve a problem’ to the Programming in Python module within the Meta Back-End Developer Professional Certificate in Coursera.

It uses a for loop to iterate through num_list, and and if-else block to test whether the value is over 45 or not, f-string literal to present the output, and addition assignment to count iterations of the loop. Finally a break statement is inserted at the end of the if-statement, terminating the output and count at the end of the ‘over-45’ that I’m so close to joining.

# Inside the for loop, create a condition that will look for all numbers that are greater than 45 and print out only numbers that meet that condition
# Change the print statement to ‚ÄúOver 45‚Äù and add an else condition with a print statement of ‚ÄúUnder 45‚Äù.
# Update the for loop to use the enumerate function so you can get and use the index. Alter the condition to look for number 36 and print out the following: ‚ÄòNumber found at position: ‚Äò, index number
# Next, create a new variable called count and assign it a value of 0 and place it outside the for loop.
# Inside the for loop increment the counter by 1.
# Add a print statement outside the for loop to print the value of the count variable.
# Finally, add a break statement directly after the print statement inside the if condition for finding the number.

num_list = [33,42,5,66,77,22,16,79,36,62,78,43,88,39,53,67,89,11]
count = 0

for idx, item in enumerate(num_list):
    if item > 45:
        print(f"Over 45 at position {idx}:", item)
        break
    else:
        print(f"Under 45 at position {idx}:", item)
    count += 1

print(f"Items counted: {count}")

Trinket

üë®üèº‚Äçüíª Using the Match Case Statement in Python

Jan 25, 2024

In this post I describe the match case statement in Python, and how to use it.

I try to spend 30 minutes to an hour each day on learning to code, usually working my way through the Meta frontend and backend courses in Coursera. Then I practice what I’ve learned, and write about it here to crystallise the learning. December went pretty well, January didn’t really got going, till today.

In python and other programming languages it is really easy to find yourself writing increasingly convoluted if / elif / else blocks dealing with all the permutations of what you are trying to achieve. Match case deals with that by simplifying the arguments that you write and the amount of code needed to write them.

Before getting going though, it is worth point out that this functionality was introduced to Python in 3.10 - so you are not going to see it in legacy code, and you may need to upgrade your interpreter if the installed version is more than a couple of years old.

At the beginning of the match statement you identify the value that you wish to test, in the example below I will be testing against the variable your_club.lower(). This saves declaring the variable in each test, as I would need to do in writing an if / elif / else block.

Having identified the value to test against in the match statement, the corresponding case statements identify what should happen if that value matches. Statements are simplified further by the and/or operators & and | which provide for additional conditionality in a very straightforward way. For example, in the code below if your_club.lower() is either “blackburn’ or ‘blackburn rovers’ the value ‘Deadwood’ will be returned.

your_club = input("Please enter the name of the team you support: ")
statement = your_club + " play at: "
match your_club.lower():
    case "accrington":
        print(statement + "the Wham Stadium")
    case "blackburn" | "blackburn rovers:
        print(statement + "Deadwood")
    case "burnley":
        print(statement + "Turf Moor")
    case _:
        print("Sorry, " + your_club + " is not in our database yet.")

Trinket

Hopefully if you found this wee article you found it useful, if you did please let me know using the kudos button below, or by commenting through micro.blog or mastodon.

‚öΩÔ∏è Premier League Ticket Allocations for Visiting Supporters

Jan 20, 2024

Burnley play Liverpool at Anfield on 10 February, and I was really disappointed on Thursday when Burnley’s ticket allocation of 1,900 seats sold out before sales opened to my category the following morning.

There are almost 55,000 seats at Anfield, and an allocation of 1,900 seems particularly light - though in line with previous allocations to Burnley at Anfield. Given the pace with which they sold out, and the accessibility of Liverpool from Burnley, I’m sure that we would fill at least double that allocation.

I wanted to try to understand why the allocation was so paltry so, as a lawyer, I turned to the Premier League Handbook 2023-24 to try to establish why this was so. I also wanted to understand where the various quotas came from that I could find being quoted across the internet.

Rule R.9 (p.236) provides:

Unless otherwise agreed by the Board or between the Clubs, and subject to Rule R.11, at each League Match, the Home Club shall make available to the Visiting Club the following allocation of tickets (with such allocation to be inclusive of a minimum of 10% of the Home Club‚Äôs disabled spectator accommodation in each case): R.9.1. 3,000 tickets; or R.9.2. if the capacity of the Home Club‚Äôs Stadium is less than 30,000, such number of tickets as is equal to 10% of its Stadium capacity.

So as a starting point Liverpool should be offering a ticket allocation of at least 3,000 tickets to Burnley. Reading more widely, Liverpool offering allocations below 3,000 to visiting supporters seems to be a fairly common occurence 1, 2. While the guidance to the rule provides for approval of a lower allocation only where:

  1. A reduced allocation is required to ensure that the game can go ahead at the time scheduled

or

  1. The club has informed the league before taking the proposal to the Safety Advisory Group, and
  2. The home club has meaningfully consulted with the visiting club, and
  3. A detailed process of consideration and consultation has been followed seeking to mitigate or avoid the reduction to the allocation.

and crucially:

Where Board approval has been granted in accordance with this Rule, that approval will be time-limited (whether to a particular League Match or such other period as the Board deems appropriate). The Club concerned will be expected to take such remedial action during the close Season as necessary to ensure that no similar issues arise during the following Season.

As the allocation we received two years ago was the same 1,900, well below 3,000 this seems to be incompatible with that carve out - why?

I understand that there has been a long running expansion project at Anfield, so assume it relates to this - but I’d have more sympathy for these reductions if half of the ground would not be full of two tone scarf wearing tourists anyway. For balance, from what I’ve seen so far, I’m sure half of the away end will be full of tourists also.

üë®üèº‚Äçüíª I’ve not noticed micro.blog stability issues I’ve been reading about.

From time to time the service has issues…A post will show up on Mastodon with no photos, or another one won‚Äôt make it at all. Maybe I‚Äôll write something, and then wait an hour before the post shows up on the blog… What if?

I did notice a few months ago that if I use large image file sizes, the images sometimes did not syndicate through. Since using shortcuts to upload and resize all images, I’ve not seen this again.

Once a new post sat in posts not reaching the timeline - a rebuild cleared this problem for me.

‚öΩÔ∏è There is no point to a video referee system, that simply takes mistakes on the fields and amplifies them.

The technology is great, but so long as the people sat behing it are drawn from the same cohort of people making the mistakes on the pitch, I‚Äôd rather live with the on-field bias.

I‚Äôm out.

‚öΩÔ∏è Match Report: Burnley 1 Luton Town 1

Jan 12, 2024

I said before the game that I thought that if this game was not ‘must win’, it was definitely ‘must not lose’. Burnley did not lose, but this will feel like another two points lost.

Luton started really well, bringing a good couple of saves out of James Trafford, and they would have felt aggrieved when Odobert cut back to Amdouni towards the end of the first half, who somehow managed to get the ball over the line from around 15m out. I’ve watched it back 5 times, I’ve still no idea how that ball crosses the line. Their number 7 Ogbene had been particularly impressive on the right wing all first half.

Burnley did a much better job of shutting Luton out in the second half, and spurned a couple of good chances to extend our lead with Foster and Vitinho not alone in drawing saves from Kaminski.

Around the 75th minute Kompany used his substitues to switch to a 541, effectively parking the bus. That did not quite work against West Ham, and it did not quite work here either.

In the third minute of injury time Luton equalised controversially. Carlton Morris firing home after James Trafford had been brought down by Adebayo.

I’m fed up of talking about referees, but Tony Harrington was dreadful today, probably even worse than Bobby Madley was on wednesday. I counted Foster being held back 5 times at the start of a counter-attack. Not just wee holds mind, these could more accurately described as bear hugs. Not one foul. When Foster was pulled down to break the counter no yellow card. When Foster was kicked off the pitch, no foul, and we had to play with 10 men for a minute. Then the goal, Adebayo, who is not playing for ball, moves backwards into Trafford who is moving forward to collect the incoming cross. I was amazed that the referee did not blow for the foul, even more amazed that VAR did not give it, and having watched it back I’m even more amazed - it is cynical, and it is obstruction. Maybe this is one of those that, when you slow it down looks innocuous - but at match speed, thats a free kick.

I think Luton were good for a point, and I think they would have felt disappointed to leave with nothing - but that is an appalling decision by both the referee, and the VAR. I don’t think any of the commentary team expected that goal to stand, and I cannot think of a single game where I’ve seen the goalkeeper impeded in that way and the foul not be given. It’s another shocking decision, and if VAR cannot see that, there is no point to VAR whatsoever - it’s clear, obvious, and the referee has missed it.

The BBC say that we are 4 points from safety, thats to Everton though and I think thats the wrong test. I think we are 7-9 points from the teams that we need to pass to stay up. Our form is currently stronger than Brentford, and on a par with Crystal Palace, while Nottingham Forest have turned a corner, and I expect Everton to also pull clear. There are 17 games left, but we have played more games than all of the teams around us - it could be 10 to 12 points by the time this round of matches is complete, and thats as many points as we’ve collected in the first 19 games. We should have collected many more points from the positions that we have been in during the first half of the season though, so its not impossible to envisage that we could put a run together and lift ourselves clear.

Jan 12, 2024

‚öΩÔ∏è At Turf Moor feeling pensive ahead of what feels like one of the defining games of the season. For me, if this is not must win - and I think it is, then absolutely do not lose.

Up the clarets.

‚öΩÔ∏è Accrington Stanley 1 Bolton Wanderers 3

Jan 10, 2024

I was back at the Wham Stadium this evening following a short work trip over to Norwich, to see Stanley take on Bolton in last 16 of the Bristol Street Motors Trophy / EFL Trophy.

Apparently Accrington / Bolton is somewhat of a local derby. Bolton sold out half the stadium, buying a ticket was pretty difficult, and the police presence huge. Not sure the Stanley fans got the message - the home attendance considerably below that at home to Salford in the league a few weeks ago.

Stanley started well, applying good pressure on the Bolton goal, but Bolton looked dangerous on the break. Jerome pounced on an underpowered back-pass to lob the goalkeeper, putting Bolton in the lead, out came the blue flares. Morley doubled the lead on 29 minutes from what looked to be a very weak penalty decision.

Henderson pulled one back for Stanley in the 37th, stealing the ball back and driving forward, before placing the ball in the bottom right corner, in front of the Bolton fans on the terrace. Stanley had a number of chances to equalise, Nolan missing a really good opening in the 62nd minute sending the ball right back across goal, when it looked easier to put it in the net.

Dempsey settled the game in the 83, collecting a clearance, driving forward, and placing the ball in the same right corner of the net in front of the away terrace. He was allowed far too much time and space, but the finish was sublime.

Worst performance of the night goes to the referee Bobby Madley, inconsistent and one sided throughout. The worst of which was failing to produce a yellow card for a cynical pull back as Stanley broke clear. Far too many misdemeanours to list here.

Bolton were good for their win, they looked much more incisive, though Stanley should be pleased with the statistics that show they held a decent proportion of the ball and put more shots on target than their opponents from the division above.

Website theme upgrade - 1987 Theme

Jan 3, 2024

My objective for this vacation was to build a theme from scratch for my website. Within that there were a few functional objectives.

  • I did not want to show the same intro text in the banner of each page, though I like it on the front page.
  • I had a loose idea that I liked line per item archive pages, on a single page.
  • I definitely wanted to have custom archive introductions, and had already come up with a way to produce that, but it used a partial template for each variant.
  • I felt that a last modified date would be a useful thing to automate given that as well as writing content this year, I want to get better at gardening and maintaining existing content too.

It took me about a day to design my concept in html and css. A claret and blue themed page which I decided to call 1987. Originally this had a single column page structure, and two column post structure - with post meta and discussion displayed to the right. While I liked that design, I felt that it would be complicating the responsive design in production, and might create problems that I could not solve with my limited css skills - so I reverted to a single column post-design when I came to build it.

Having designed the theme in html and css, I needed to work out how to theme it onto Hugo. Attempting to do this in Micro.Blog would have caused a ridiculous number of rebuilds, and would have slowed the whole project down. So I followed @mandaris series on how to set up a Hugo development server on a local machine for developing on, downloaded a copy of the blank theme for micro.blog from github, and put a little test content into my Hugo install to make sure it was running properly.

Having created a few test posts, I thought it would make sense to bulk import much more content. When I downloaded my archive from micro.blog I could see in the yaml frontmatter that micro.blog wast tracking the lastmod property - and suddenly became very excited that I would be able to find a way to pull the last modified date directly within the template.

This first image shows the front page design. The intro text is currently hard coded, though that can be pulled through directly from Micro.Blog.

I have written a custom index.html file, negating the need for the custom front page plugin. To the top of the page I have written a script pulling through the 5 most recent posts. To the bottom is my digital garden, which I had to convert from the markdown into html.

At the bottom of the page in the footer area I originally had 4 x footer blocks running horizontally, though I ran out of ideas about what to put in them. So I consolidated that area into a single bock. I have added a category block so that the category archives are accessible from every page in the site, and below that are links to the indieWeb and Tinylytics webrings that my site is part of.

I quite like the way that @jsonbecker presents the post archive in his theme, titled posts only, with a very clean archive listing. I wanted to replace my archive page with something similar, so I have removed untitled posts from my archive page, presenting only titled articles on a line per item basis. I have also added the categorisation to the end of each line.

I did not want to just lose short form posts in their entirety though, and they serve a different purpose to articles in my site though. So as you can see in the image below, they are presented in their own stream of snips, or microposts, along with a preview of any images in the post. That is populated directly from the snips category, that I have set micro.blog up to filter all of my untitled posts into by default.

The default micro.blog photos page drives me crazy. There is nothing particularly wrong with it, I just hate galleries with whitespace caused by a mix of portrait and landscape orientation photos. I have used the css cover and max-height properties to provide a more consistent grid.

The Today page was a real challenge, I’ll talk about this more on a subsequent ’lessons learned’ article. However it took me probably a full day of exploring that code and implementation to understand why it was not working, and to refactor my code so that it would.

While wanting to use the archive layout from above on my category archives, I did not want to lose the untitled posts from these pages. On the archive page below on programming the microposts are listed, but still presented in a very truncated fashion. Note also the custom category introduction in the hero banner for this page.

There is a subtitles.html partial within my theme, which contains a series of if/else if/else statements, populating this area of the template based on the title of the page. This has introduced a little weirdness where there is a page in my digital garden with the same name. I can live with that for now, but will probably refactor soon to correct this.

While that approach worked really well for the informational sections of my site, it did not feel so great for the more ‘instagram’ sections. I’m probably the biggest reader of my site, and I wanted to be able to look at bayLee’s section on my site, and scroll up from his posts as a puppy at the beginning, and see him grow up - without having to open each post to see what it contained. So I have retained a more traditional archive page layout for these sections. I have not had time to rewrite this layout, which is largely borrowed from Tiny Theme.

There is a piece of conditional logic in the list template which depending on the title of the category will either load in a partial with the more minimalist archive layout, or a partial with post previews. In general terms pages about my canine children and Vickie are laid out in preview form, and components of my digital garden largely deploy the more minimalist approach.

Finally, the below post section on each post, and most pages, provides a visually clear way for the reader to say thanks for the time and effort that went into writing this, as well as information about when that page was last updated. This felt particularly important for the more ’evergreen’ pages that collate and curate my digital garden.

For the most part the development went really well, it probably took me a day to design the theme, and 3-4 days to revise and build the design onto Hugo. I got a few things wrong along the way, and there are a few things that I would do differently next time. I’ll write a follow up article about the lessons learned. If there is sufficient interest I may do a screencast on setting Hugo up ready for theming, which was definitely my biggest bar to getting going with this project. I’m pretty pleased with the outcome, I’ve made a few revisions since the theme went live, and I’ve a couple of minor tweaks left to do before I merge the amendments made live back into my github repo and local build.

I hope that you found the article interesting or useful. If you did, please just click on the kudos button below to say thanks, or feel free to comment through micro.blog, mastodon or email using the links below..

Jan 2, 2024

üí≠ I wrote last night in my 2023 Review about excluding more social media noise to maintain focus on my actual goals. Since then I’ve:

  • Deactivated Instagram & Threads
  • Blocked LinkedIn so that I can only use it on work hardware
  • Blocked Facebook so that I can use it only sparsely on my Chromebook ‚è≠Ô∏è

My 2023 in Review üí≠

Jan 1, 2024

As we move in to 2024 I wanted to take the opportunity to reflect on 2023, to identify what went well, what did not, and to set some foundations for the year ahead.

Planning

Having set SMART objectives at the beginning of the year would have made it really easy to reflect on the year that has passed. Having not done so makes it really hard to objectively measure performnce… so I will set some specific objectives where I can for 2024.

Work

Work was an unmitigated disaster.

In January 2023 I left a role that I had been very successful in across a number of years, to work for another consultancy. All that I can say on this topic is that the role did not have the seniority and profile or autonomy that I expected and thrive under.

I left at the end of the year to take up a position as Head of Technical Services at another consultancy that I have a lot of respect for and trust in. So 2023 was üí©, but the year ahead is an exciting one professionally.

Fitness

I entered 2023 weighing 81.77kg, and exited at 84kg. That does not tell the full story though, peaking at 86kg in June, my weight has been gradually falling from there into the end of the year.

I spent 170h training in 2023. From a promising position at the end of the summer, COVID and a deteriorating work-life combined to make for a pretty miserly end to 2023 - just 19 hours of activity in the last three months of the year.

Of those 19 hours, 4 were at one of my target races for the year - the Manchester Half Marathon, which I walked. It really illustrates just how badly the end of the year went.

I have always used my fitness metrics as an indicator of the strength of my work life balance, and mental wellbeing - the peaks and troughs in that data show how consuming the year was at times.

Software Development

In January 2023 I completed a software engineering course with HyperionDev.

I didn’t set any objectives around this, but I’d have expected to kick on and learn more in 2023. There were probably some really obvious starting points as well, that course being threadbare on Flask and Django in particular.

I have learned a little through the year. Moving and consolidating all of my websites into a single site on Micro.Blog has meant that I have had to learn quite a bit about the Hugo static site generator on which it sits. That has culminated in me designing almost all of my own theme from scratch, which starts to think innovatively about how to make Micro.Blog do things that would have been much easier if the YAML frontmatter were exposed.

This is not completely new. I have built much more complex sites / data structures in Jekyll on Github Pages in the past. I think this is the most comprehensive theme that I have ever written though, without using third party components like bootstrap.

Social Media

At the end of 2022 I spent quite a lot of time looking for places to write with communities around them. I stumbled across micro.blog, I also spent quite a bit of time looking at write.as, I looked at Ghost, and probably a few others too.

I found micro.blog intriguing, and though the web presence has been much improved over the last year, I really couldn’t work out why everybody on Micro.Blog had built Hugo Websites. Once I realised that I could both write to an audience, and to do that through my own websites, I was pretty sold.

I wrote about this more at the time, but have used micro.blog and its activitypub capability to eliminate more nefarious social media sources from my life.

That process is not complete though.

  • I still have Facebook, Instagram and Threads accounts. I need the former mainly for the various virtual cycling groups I am in that organise themselves there. Maybe after the Zwift Racing League is finished for the year I will be able to do something about that. I do not need either the instagram or threads accounts.

  • I also still have a LinkedIn account. I probably need to retain that for professional purposes, but need to be much more effective in my usage, avoiding doomscrolling there.

Conclusions

2023 was a really tough year, physically, but mentally as well. I’ve probably been to darker places in the last year than I ever have before, so it is cathartic to look back over on the year now. I think that I’m much better placed, and positioned in a much better place, for the year ahead. So turning to the year ahead:

Objectives for 2024

Fitness 260 training hours (5 per week) excluding walking Running Sub 1:45 Half Marathon at Great North Run Running Sub 23min Parkrun / 5km Weight Sub 78kg at year end Financial Reduce net debt Software Develop a specific niche wee application that I’ve had in mind for a while - which means that I need to learn the technology to deliver it Interweb Hibernate Facebook/Instagram/Threads accounts, consolidate fitness data into the Suunto app as the primary source. Digital Garden Complete upload of missing mountain photographs from 2004-9 Home Be kind

Happy new year, see you on the other side!

Jan 1, 2024

üèÉ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è5.1km | 31:10 | 6:04/km | 446kcal - Burnley Parkrun

Starting off the year with my first Burnley Parkrun in quite a while, and my first outdoor run in a few months. Not my fastest time, possibly my slowest, but that was not really the point.

Suunto Activity Link

Match Report: Aston Villa 3 Burnley 2 ‚öΩÔ∏è

Dec 31, 2023

I wrote yesterday about my visit to Villa Park. Usually I’d write about the game at the same time, but I want to organise this data better in this site, and I also wanted to organise my thoughts about this game better too.

On paper this was a very tough game against opponents second in the league, and who beat us with ease at Turf Moor earlier in the season.

In many ways Burnley’s approach to the game showed how despite the rhetoric to the contrary, the playing style has evolved through the season. The squad churn of the early weeks is gone, Kompany having settled on his best combination. The only change from mid-week being Johann Berg Gudmundsson replacing Mike Tresor on right wing. Gone too was the high press that Aston Villa went straight through in August, replaced with soaking up pressure at the back, while still playing out from the back, and countering through Villa’s high press.

The game started as expected, plenty of Villa pressure and possession, generally coped with well. Trafford saved an instinctive reflex volley from Ollie Watkins in the 13th minute, a good save, but one you’d expect to be made. Sadly Jordan Beyer had to be replaced shortly afterwards by Hannes Delcroix. Having been integral to improved resilience at the back since his return to the team, lets hope he returns again before too long - thankfully the month ahead is very light on program.

The first Villa goal came shortly after the first decent spell of pressure from Burnley, in which Josh Brownhill forced Martinez into a save from a shot from range. Again, a save that you would expect Martinez to make. Watkins drove out to left, before cutting back and across O’Shea, placing the ball behind Bailey. A fortunate deflection sent Bailey’s strike straight into the roof of Trafford’s net.

Burnley did not have to wait long for the equaliser. Josh Brownhill floated in a free kick across the penalty box from the left wing. The cross found the head of Dara O’Shea, who played it back across the goal for Zeki Amdouni to acrobatically find, and to place in the roof of Martinez’s goal.

It got better still shortly afterwards when Lyle Foster raced through from the halfway line to fire past Martinez, only for the linesman to raise his flag, and the VAR to confirm. I’m really struggling to be convinced that the lines were drawn properly, and can be drawn with sufficient accuracy to split two players that are as level as this. I’ve only seen one more marginal this this - which (not) coincidentally was also another disallowed Burnley goal earlier in the season where the lines had to be redrawn when they gave the wrong answer first time.

Villa went back ahead just before half time, Watkins taking the ball out to the left wing, and crossing for Diaby to fire home from close range. Fatefully after the goal Sander Berge was booked for a tackle on Jacob Ramsey after a ridiculous passage of play which had lasted a good couple of minutes - and for which the referee had not awarded a foul, even after Burnley extinguished any advantage. It was a soft yellow card, but would contribute to Berge’s dismissal early in the second half for the tiniest of tugs on the shirt of Douglas Luis. It was a nothing challenge, but Attwell did not hesitate to produce the second yellow.

Heading down to 10 men, I probably feared the worst, but Burnley played as well with 10 men as Villa did with 12. The referee’s most unforgivable mistake of the game coming on 60 minutes. Foster charging on the Villa goal. Diego Carlos got to the ball first, miscued it into the path of Foster, and then controls the ball with his left arm on the edge of the penalty area. The handball was really obvious from the Upper Doug Ellis Stand over 100m away. The referee is stood 20 yards away with a clear view of it. Watching it back, the ball does not strike the arm, the arm changes position to control the ball which is flying on by. It is a really shocking decision, it prevented Foster going through one on one with Martinez, and it should have resulted in a red card and a free kick. If VAR does not intervene in something as appalling clear and obvious as that, then there is absolutely no point to it whatsoever.

Foster equalised on the 71st minute, racing through and firing below Martinez at his near post from the right.

Burnley managed the game well from here until on the cusp of 90 minutes Bailey got ahead of Charlie Taylor, playing across to Dur√†n, who promptly fell to the ground on the slightest of contacts from Aaron Ramsey who was playing the ball that he had intercepted. It’s debatable that there is any contact - certainly not sufficient to warrant the simulation on the floor in any case, and the referee is the wrong side of the action to see it either way. If there is contact, it is with less of Ramsey’s foot than the bit of Foster’s foot that allegedly strayed offside.

It was a really good Burnley performance, with 5 shots on target to Villa’s 7. Maybe Villa edged it, but even they will feel fortunate to have escaped from that game with all three points - the comments from their fans on the match page on the BBC reflects that. The officiating was appallingly bad - VAR was supposed to eradicate mistakes from the game, but it feels worse than ever. The offside is really close, but fair enough. Both Berge yellow cards are hideously soft. The penalty is really soft. The handball is just plain wrong.

I hate sour grapes. I’ve tried to be really balanced on officiating and on our performances - but I can’t recall another game where so many key, but marginal, decisions all went one way. Stuart Attwell should reflect on his performance, PGMOL should on theirs too. Neither will, as it was not an hysterical Liverpool or Man City on the wrong end of their shocking incompetence. Dreadful, dreadful refereeing - not what any supporter in the ground pays to see.

Villa Park

Dec 30, 2023

My take, as a visiting supporter, of Villa Park.

Villa Park is the home of Aston Villa in Birmingham, with a capacity of 42,657 across the Doug Ellis, Holte End, Trinity Road and North Stands.

If you arrive before the roads close there is ample coach and car parking opposite the ground on Witton Lane. You‚Äôll find the program sellers dotted around there too. ¬£3.50 is amongst the cheapest programs in the Premier League this season.

The stadium is surrounded by food vendors, including at the expansive fan zone in front of the North Stand. There was even a wee concert going on there while I explored around the stadium.

My advice, as a travelling supporter, would be to get food and drink at one of those vendors - Smokey Joes have a number of stalls around the ground that looked really good.

Once you gain access to the Doug Ellis Stand, the concourse is really disappointing. In fact concourse is stretching it, the facilities in that stand could be politely and more accurately be described as a corridor.

Food and drink is served from a hatch in the corridor, a Mill Town beef and onion pie, it was fine - a gentrified steak bake at best, and costs ¬£5.30. Which means that my Bovril must have cost an extraordinary ¬£3.20. For a mug of hot water and a stock cube. Not the worst pie or pricing this season, but disappointing all the same.

The toilets are just grim, and there is nowhere to eat and drink in the corridor, so you might as well just head through to your seat and eat there.

Don‚Äôt bother entering early, enjoy the facilities around the ground, even take a stroll around Aston Hall Park. Avoid booking seats 1-17 of the Upper Doug Ellis Stand, especially below row GG - unless you want to stare at the back of a television. You can thank me later!

The pre game fire and light show was perplexing. The fire was nice, and you could feel the warmth from the jets. But it was not dark, why the light show?

The stadium itself is excellent, a large classic ‚Äòproper‚Äô football stadium. Not a soulless bowl. The steep terraced seating really adds to the atmosphere in the ground.

The facilities for visiting supporters though are easily the worst that I have seen so far in the Premier League this season. Given that Villa might well make the Champions League next season, are cultured Barcelona and Monaco supporters really going to be greeted with that? I suspect so.

Visits to Villa Park on this website

30 December 2023 - Aston Villa 3 Burnley 2

‚öΩÔ∏èüì∑ Match Report: Burnley 0 Liverpool 2

Dec 26, 2023

The visit of Liverpool to Turf Moor was always going to be a tough game to try to build on the fine away victory at Fulham on Saturday. With Man City and Arsenal, Liverpool are one of three teams who can realistically win the Premier League this year.

Out brightly, Burnley probably had the better of the first 5 minutes of the first half Darwin Nu√±ez putting Liverpool ahead clinically in the 6th minute. The remainder of the first half was painful viewing, and only a string of fine saves from James Trafford, and a foul in the build up to Gapko’s disallowed goal kept the score to 0 - 1.

The second half was much better. Another Liverpool goal was disallowed for offside interference with play from Mo Salah. From the 70th minute onwards Burnley looked much more likely to equalise than Liverpool to extend their lead. None of the chances created could be taken, then Diogo Jota finished well from a difficult angle to extend the lead in the 90th.

Trafford had another fine game, if his distribution continues to improve, there is a really good goalkeeper in there. Similarly Odobert terrorised the left wing again, carrying strong delivery and goal threat. Foster looks stronger and sharper each game, and I thought that Amdouni had a really good game too, as did Beyer in defence. Mike Tresor took a little stick from the crowd, but I though his ball control was excellent as Trafford’s distribution lengthened, he did well at picking the ball out of the air, holding and taking it forward.

Burnley looked vulnerable to the Liverpool press playing out from the back. Berge did not hit the levels that he can, with a couple of passes going astray in dangerous transitions. Probably the biggest criticism is the lack of conviction to shoot in dangerous positions.

Next up on Saturday is Aston Villa at Villa Park. Hopefully they will not feel too aggrieved at my first paragraph. Villa, who are having an excellent season themselves, currently sit third in the league.

‚öΩÔ∏è Mike Tresor in for Jacob Bruun Larsen the only change from the Burnley team that beat Fulham on Saturday. Well deserved.

‚öΩÔ∏èüèüÔ∏èüì∑ Match Report - Fulham 0 Burnley 2

Dec 23, 2023

Leaving Burnley this morning, I wasn‚Äôt particularly optimistic. It has felt like a season where we have started to play really well, but rarely consistently and long enough to translate it into points. I was much more excited about seeing a heritage football stadium and pie sampling than I was the football. In fact I was feeling so uninspired about the football, that I started a whole new section on my site about motorway services instead. I recently stumbled across the full men‚Äôs blog on the facewall, which seems to have impacted my interests!

As usual I travelled down with Burnley Supporters Club, getting on the coach at 06:20 opposite Queensgate bus depot in Burnley. Travelling down in no time to Norton Canes services on the M6 Toll, my plan to wait for the queue to go down before ordering a coffee at McDonalds, when the Fleetwood coach pulled in, followed by Watford and Everton. The Watford lot were in vocal form, though given that they went to the dark side of Oswaldthwistle and won today, I‚Äôll forgive them.

The stadium holds you outside a bit longer than other stadiums, it must have been at least 13:30 before we were allowed in. Before that we got to watch the bizarre spectacle of a box of stewards reserving drop off spaces for the incoming team coaches, pushing the waiting crowd in and out. A bit perplexed as to why you would need to get a coach to your own stadium but still.

The Johnny Haynes stand is a delight, with the heritage red brick frontage, and what looked like timber seating to the rear of the stand. The away section is in the Putney Stand, walking in past the cottage and what looks like an old police box. The refreshment areas under the stand felt pretty unique in that the spare is shared by home and visiting support.

The praise stops there. Refreshment prices were ridiculous. ¬£5.70 for a pretty ordinary looking pie felt obscenely expensive. Yes I can afford ¬£6 for a pie, and no I absolutely won‚Äôt pay it. The sausages looked amazing, but felt like far too much to eat. ¬£9.50 for that beast felt much more sensible.

For some reason the Riverside stand is left deliberately half empty. The stand on the left of the photos has two entire banks of the upper tier left completely empty. It looks deliberate / planned - why?

The first half was a pretty poor performance. We never really looked in trouble, but we did not look like we would threaten, it felt laggy, with no incision or pace, and there were a couple of really solid saves from James Trafford in the Burnley goal.

At half time Jacob Bruun Larsen was substituted out for Mike Tresor. Burnley struck early in the half with Odobert, laid off by Foster, putting a world class finish into Leno‚Äôs top left corner, leaving the keeper with no chance.

We never really controlled possession like we can, but still looked fairly solid at the back despite a couple of whoupsies. Thankfully for once this season we were able to prevent the other side from capitalising on those moments in the game.

Around 20 minutes later Odobert teed up Sander Berge, who placed the ball pretty bluntly into Leno‚Äôs top right corner. All contributing to a new chorus - you better watch out, you better not cry, Sander Berge is coming to town.

From that point forward Burnley managed the game out quite well, never looking like collapsing in the manner of the West Ham defeat. We were definitely under pressure, but handled it well.

The game was also notable for Rebecca Walsh becoming the first female to referee a game in the Premier League. For me she had a solid performance, controlling the teams well and getting the key decisions right. She was too accommodating of Fulham players falling over every time they were tackled. For a while there, it did not feel like we were allowed to actually tackle.

Delighted with the result, really struggled with my man of the match. Trafford played well, Berge had a solid game also, Foster turned and ran through a number of times, and just needs to release when thr opportunity opens up. My man of the match nomination went to Odabert who terrorised on both wings at times, cutting in, and going round. A stunning goal and an essential assist really wrapped it up for me.

I‚Äôve felt from the beginning of the season that Koleosho on one wing and Odabert on the other is a very appealing combination, though sadly it will be the end of the season before that is possible.

Rumour has it that Nathan Tella was watching in the Cottage with Alan Pace‚Ä¶ who walked right past us when we were waiting to get in. Rumour mill in full flow.

Hope that you enjoyed the article, if you did please feel free to say so by clicking the give kudos button below, it makes me feel less like I‚Äôm talking to myself!

Liverpool next, on Tuesday at the Turf. Up the Clarets!

Dec 23, 2023

üé•üèüÔ∏è‚öΩÔ∏è Craven Cottage - a short clip of supporters dispersing after Fulham v Burnley tonight.

Dec 23, 2023

üì∑üõ£Ramping up the excitement factor on my page by talking about motorway service stations. Here’s Norton Canes on the M6 Toll this morning.

Service Stations

Dec 23, 2023

Bit confused as to why the two sets of media I’ve uploaded using my iOS Shortcut this morning ended up in the media library of my new test blog, and not my main one. Any ideas why?

Norton Canes Services

Dec 23, 2023

In the first of a new collection on my site, I decided to start documenting the various service stations that I visit. Just because.

Roadchef operated Norton Canes services sits on the M6 Toll not too far from Cannock. It seems to be a popular stopping point for football traffic, with Burnley, Fleetwood, Everton and Watford all in this morning.

The services benefits from a McDonalds, Leon, Spar, Costa Coffee as well as a large seating area.

Outside the services is set in expansive wooded grounds with a good dog walk loop up to a monument providing views across the area from above.

Externally the services is complemented by a Costa drive through - which appears to be drive through only, and a BP filling station with Wildbean Cafe.

Hopefully you found this article useful. If you get excited about seeing motorway service stations, see the curated list that L’m building in my digital garden. If you enjoyed this, please feel free to say thanks by clicking the Kudos button below.

Until next time. See you on the road.

Dec 23, 2023

‚öΩÔ∏èüöê Another long trip South begins. Fulham v Burnley at Craven Cottage today.

#clarets

Dec 19, 2023

üë®üèº‚Äçüíª After most a year on micro.blog, I’ve just arrived at a method to inject custom content into category pages on my site using if/else in the list template to load in the related partial.

I’m sure there will be a much leaner way, but I’m happy after faffing around trying to do this for months.

Very excited that my test blog is up and running.

Hoping to learn enough Go over the winter festival to retheme my own site from scratch with custom home and taxonomy pages‚Ä¶. See how far I get!

‚öΩÔ∏èüì∑ Match Report: Burnley 0 Everton 2

Dec 16, 2023

Selected as the Saturday evening game by Sky Sports, today marked the first return back to Turf Moor of Sean Dyche, James Tarkowski, and Dwight McNeill.

The two teams met just a few months ago in a somewhat turgid affair at Goodison, where Burnley dominated the ball, but could do little with it and were punished at the back. The fear going into the game was a repeat of that.

On the back of a decent run of form, the Cricket Field Stand was as lively as I’ve heard it this season, and the returning clarets were given a fine welcome, unlike some of the treatment handed out to Dwight at Goodison.

The team rewarded this too, with a lively first ten or fifteen minutes where Burnley were again very much on top.

Ten minutes in the Everton fans held their little pink “Premier League: Corrupt” posters up, and sang their “Premier League Corrupt as …” chant. The irony that they were singing that song at the home of a team who were relegated behind them in the years they were busily overspending should not be lost.

Authors of our own misfortune again, the team just do not seem to be capable of playing out from the back, inviting pressure. Trafford made a fine save before the the first goal, but was beaten in the air from the following corner by Onana.

The second goal also followed a fine save by Trafford, but O’Shea could only defect into the path of fellow claret diaspora member, Michael Keane.

I think both goals followed weak attempts to play out from the back, and O’Shea was very fortunate not to concede a third with an appalling touch putting Everton clear.

We had our chances in the game. Amdouni conspired not to score when it seemed easier to score than not in the first period. In the second half Sander Berge struck the crossbar with force. For the most part though we were reduced to efforts from range, and attempting to run through behind the defence. The lack of penetration really hurts - especially once behind.

Some positives.

  • In full flow, this team really begins to look like it belongs at this level, though in practice in needs to do that for much bigger periods of the game.
  • Lyle Foster, returning to the squad from illness, made his first appearance in a while, replacing Rodriguez at half time.
  • Manuel Benson also made his first appearance of any description since probably August. His cameo of 15 minutes or so definitely produced better deliveries into dangerous areas, but lacked the firepower on the end of it
  • Al-Dakhil also came on for the first time in a month or so, replacing Hannes Delcroix who sadly still looks out of his depth at this level. Al-Dakhil looked like he had regained some of his confidence and composure, after a tough start to the season.

Its Fulham away next on Saturday 23 December, and I’m getting very excited about my trip to Craven Cottage. Another classic ground with lots of history - I can’t wait to see it.

Until next time, up the clarets!

Dec 16, 2023

‚öΩÔ∏è Heading out at sunset for Burnley v Everton in the Saturday evening game.

#burnleyfc

Dec 15, 2023

üêïüì∑ Stevie has always liked his own space, though Fearghus has taken to sitting on him until he submits and provides warmth.

Accommodation for business travel is so overrated.

I‚Äôm staying in a perfectly functional Days Inn at Corley tonight. Heading into the services for breakfast is a bit naff, but the cost makes up for it.

Sharing one of my favourite West Wing cuts, without any subliminal political statement whatsoever.

üêïüì∑ While I make my way back north from Brighton, here‚Äôs Stevie and Caoimhe looking concerned at the storm passing through Burnley.

‚öΩÔ∏èüì∑ Match report: Brighton and Hove Albion 1 Burnley 1

Dec 9, 2023

I remember categorically saying that I would not be going to Brighton, just a few weeks ago. However, my Social Events Executive Vickie knew that I wanted to see the Amex, so she booked the coach and ticket anyway.

Getting up for the supporters club coach to leave Queensgate bus station at 06:20 was pretty rough on the back of my new employer‚Äôs Christmas party, arriving back from Stoke at 11. Thankfully, I don‚Äôt drink - there is no way I would have been getting up. It‚Äôs been a pretty attritious year for a number of reasons, so I‚Äôm pretty tired and hanging on for the upcoming break.

The ride down was largely smooth, stopping off at Sandbach for a hot chocolate on the way South. We didn‚Äôt really hit any traffic until the M25. By the time we hit that I had completed a decent slant of Meta‚Äôs backend developer course on Coursera (which I like so far - more another time). Though I felt incredibly travel sick trying to complete the exercises after joining local roads.

We arrived at the American Express Stadium around 13:30, before the full range of pies had been cooked in three concourse.

The concourse area for away supporters is pretty small at the Amex - expect to have to battle your way through the queues to get to the counter, toilets or out to the stands.

The food was very similar to the offer at Brentford. The local pie seller here is Piglet Pies, with a pie and coffee costing ¬£7.70. The guest pie of the day was lamb kofta. It tasted exactly the same as the chicken tikka pie at Brentford, though the pastry was far more robust.

For a bowl the atmosphere is fairly lively, though a highlight of the afternoon was some very high pitched voices screaming ‚Äòwho are ya?‚Äô at us every couple of minutes, and their accompanying ‚Äòadults‚Äô with their monkey hand gestures. Very refined.

We‚Äôve been playing really well since the Brentford game, often not getting what we deserved from games. This was probably the opposite, a good point taken from a team who were much stronger than us for all but the first 15 minutes. I‚Äôll take that right now.

After that Brighton began to dominate, but with Burnley looking threatening on the break - with Odabert looking a more than an able cover for Luca Koleosho, who will miss much of the remainder of the season following an injury picked up against Wolves on Tuesday night.

That‚Äôs particularly bad news, as Koleosho has provided many of the brightest moments of this season. At least micro.blog should stop filtering most of my football posts into my canine child ‚ÄúLeo‚Äù category for the next while.

Just before half time Odabert cut inside from the left wing, finding the top left corner of the goal with a slight deflection to assist. Every time he cut in, Wilson created chaos in the Brighton defence. Not sure he has Luca‚Äôs pace, but his end product feels less raw. Both in the same team would be a frightening pairing.

Just after half time the score should have been extended to 2-0. The initial shorting coming again from Odabert cutting in, and Rodriguez should have done much better with the rebound which he struggled to dig out with his feet.

After that it was one way traffic, relentless Brighton pressure paying off with an equaliser 15 minutes from time.

James Trafford made a string of fine saves in the Burnley goal, with a couple of world class saves in 8 agonising minutes of added time.

We‚Äôve played much better this season for no return. Despite their dominance, Brighton did not really look like scoring before their equaliser, many of the chances they had bring fired straight at the keeper from range, or off target.

I‚Äôll wrap this up with a chant we‚Äôve not really heard before:

I like it, I like it, I la-la-la like it, la-la-la like it‚Ä¶ Super James Trafford in Goal.

There‚Äôs a fantastic young stopper in there, just need to improve distribution and box control.

Up the clarets.

Dec 9, 2023

‚öΩÔ∏è At the American Express Stadium, hoping for another good performance, and maybe a good result to go with it. Brighton & Hove Albion v Burnley.

Dec 2, 2023

‚öΩÔ∏è Sadly I cannot make Burnley v Sheffield Utd this afternoon as Vickie is away, so I’ll be chewing my fingernails at home instead. As I’ve handed my Wolves ticket back to keep workload sensible, my next game is Brighton away next weekend.

üöùüì∑ Birmingham New Street Station

Nov 27, 2023

Growing up in Walsall, Birmingham New Street was the gateway to the rest of the world.

Arriving at the station bridge, I remember being greeted by a Burger King, and the escalators out of the dungeon below, into the dungeon that was the Pallisades shopping centre. Only brightened by the presence of an Electronics Boutique at the top of the ramp down to McDonalds.

How it has changed, the Pallisades replaced by the large open expanse that is Grand Central. To be fair, the views back across the station to Grand Central are stupendous, as are those to the Bullring and more so the Rotunda at the other end.

They ought to be. A coffee will set you almost ¬£4 at and vendor, and expect to spend most ¬£3 on a cookie to go with it. Needless to say I opted instead for a ¬£5 WH Smith‚Äôs meal deal, my sandwich accompanied by a grab bag of crisps, and a litre of water for the train. All despite finally locating a pret actually stocking my favourite crayfish sandwich. Best part of ¬£8 for a sandwich, in what felt like a giant freezer, was a step too far, all a world away from my childhood.

Nov 27, 2023

üì∑üó∫Ô∏è Grand Central - Birmingham

Birmingham New Street has changed quite a bit. It feels like a lifetime ago that a grew up near here.

Nov 27, 2023

üéÆ Renewed my Crossover license for ¬£18 in the Black Friday sale.

I think a new license is same price as a renewal till midnight, and it‚Äôs a steal at that price.

Nov 26, 2023

I have started using Notion for daily note taking, replacing Obsidian.

I love Odsidian, but for changes in work environment, I would not have been looking for another tool. I’m impressed with Notion so far, it can more than fully replicate my Obsidian setup as I learn functionality.

‚öΩÔ∏èüì∑ Burnley 1 West Ham United 2

Nov 25, 2023

Burnley took on West Ham United today at Turf Moor Burnley. Read on for a summary of the match, and photographs.

I’m going to keep this article short. This is the third really good Burnley performance on the bounce, and all three of those games have ended in no points. So while we are rapidly improving, that is not translating into points, and it is frustrating to see supposedly ‘weaker’ sides picking up points against the same opposition - Luton getting a cracking result against Crystal Palace today.

So Burnley dominated this match for the first 86 minutes, deservedly leading through a Jay Rodriguez penalty at the beginning of the second half.

West Ham began to build pressure in the final 15 minutes, scoring not once but twice from moves beginning with crosses coming across the box from their right wing. In part they were able to as their substitutions gave them more pace and incision up front, while Burnley’s substitutions removed the balance in central midfield, and while Ramsay looked a class act in his cameo, removing Koleosho and Amdouni took our best players off the pitch.

Where the officials found 7 minutes of injury time from, in a pretty fluid second half, I’ve no idea. That is not why we lost though - and falling behind early in injury time there was absolutely no urgency on the ball to get back into it.

I was hoping for a good result today, and I thought that we could get something from this game - we definitely deserved too.

Though we look better and better each week - we look like we belong at this level at least now, I think we leave ourselves with far too much to do, as those around us - especially Luton and Bournemouth begin to pull away.

The last few months have been tough personally and professionally, so I was hoping for a little lift today. If the result did not provide that, the amazing “UTC” corned beef pie I arrived home to came very close.

Up the Clarets.

‚öΩÔ∏èüì∑ looks like a great day for a first home win of the season here in Burnley.

üë®üèº‚ÄçüíªAppAcademy - Day 01 - HTML Forms

Nov 13, 2023

Talking about my learning to code, and completing the HTML Forms unit of the Intermediate HTML & CSS module of the AppAcademy Open curriculum.

One of my barriers as a developer is iterating between different learning routes, without finishing, and heading back to the beginning. With the exception of the python based software engineering bootcamp that I completed with HyperionDev a year ago, I’ve really failed to kick on and build on that.

Should I follow FreeCodeCamp, The Odin Project, or AppAcademy?

FreeCodeCamp orientates heavily towards learning by doing. The Odin Project is incredibly theoretical in approach with vast amounts of material to read.

I find that I don’t take in what I learn at FreeCodeCamp, iterating back to relearn the same material over and again. I don’t take in everything that I read at the Odin Project either, by the time that I come to use it.

For me AppAcademy’s approach is somewhere between the too, more reading and instruction and underlying theory than FreeCodeCamp, but with a much faster cadence than the Odin Project. Its probably the best of the three for my learning style.

So AppAcademy it is, and to keep myself accountable I’m going to blog about the key assignments here as I complete them. I’ll also be recording my progress in a habit tracker I have created in my Obsidian vault. Obsidian is probably a topic of its won for another time.

I’m not going back to the beginning though, I don’t have anything to learn by going back over basic html/css and javascript that I already know pretty well. So I’m carrying on from where I left off a wee while back. So today I worked on the HTML Forms unit. HTML forms are not particularly difficult, but have always been anathema to me.

The content of the form is contained inside a form element, with an inner fieldset element. The form element needs action and method properties. The method, usually “post” dictates how the information collected is transferred, and the action provides the location on the server it is transferred through. If a legend element is added inside the fieldset element, the form will be boxed with the content of the legend element as title.

Each of the components of the form are wrapped inside their own div blocks, each containing a label, and input(s). As a general principle the label needs a “for” property, which must match the “id” property of the input(s) to which it relates.

Input elements need a type to be defined - in this example they include text/email/date/checkbox/radio, which tweaks the user inputs and data validation to reflect the expected data input. Where multiple radio inputs have the same name property as one another, they will work together on a single selection only basis.

Textarea and Select are different - they have their own elements and are not input types. The Select element must have the same id as the for value of its label, with option elements nested below for the choices, which will appear in a drop down list in the form.

Here’s a Replit embed providing a demonstration of all of the input fields described above, and to the specification requested by AppAcademy for submission.

Nov 12, 2023

Arsenal 3 Burnley 1

Notably the pie had the first structural failure of the season, and a fork was needed. I‚Äôm blaming that on the pointless herb inclusions in the pretentious pastry. I‚Äôd pass.

Apparently I was quite grumpy on the way home last night!

‚öΩÔ∏èüèüÔ∏èüì∑ Arsenal 3 Burnley 1

Nov 11, 2023

Photographs and match review from Arsenal v Burnley at the Emirates Stadium.

Travelling down to London on the supporters club coach, the day had an early start, walking through a moonlit Burnley for an 06:20 departure opposite Queensgate depot.

The journey down was quite uninterrupted and pleasant until we arrived at Norton Canes services on the M6 Toll. Instantly realising that every coach in the North was making its way to London today.

I‚Äôve been getting really frustrated with mobile connectivity everywhere. O2 does not seem to work at the Turf, on train or coach, or for half my drive to BoulderUK. When I try to talk to O2 about it, they do not get it. So I trialled a Vodafone PYG sim to test the network - which has worked flawlessly almost all of the day.

Notwithstanding, we made good time, arriving outside the Emirates for 12:30, with a full 2.5 hours till kick off. Just enough time to collect my program and head round to the smart shop at Holloway tube station to pick up a lightning cable to replace the one I left at home. The program looks pretty good. At ¬£4 it was the equal most expensive of the season so far, but also the biggest. Not sure what I’m doing with the fold out poster of Ben White though.

At 13:00 the stewards let us into the stadium, and I picked up a chicken balti pie, and a Lucky Saint alchohol free beer, ¬£11.50. Notably the pie had the first structural failure of the season, and a fork was needed. I‚Äôm blaming that on the pointless herb inclusions in the pretentious pastry. I‚Äôd pass.

Burnley were always in the game, but the result was probably fair. Arsenal dominated possession, but the chances were fairly even. Burnley doing a much better job of getting behind the defence than in recent weeks.

Leandro Trossard rose to at the far post to put Arsenal ahead, on the stroke of half time, injuring himself in the process.

Brownhill levelled from a Koleosho cutback 10 minutes into the second half. Apparently there was some controversy, not sure why. If the defender can manhandle the attacker off the ball it stands to reason that the reverse is true. Six of one and half a dozen of the other. Good decision!

Parity did not last long, Trafford finding himself behind Saliba at the corner, who took the opportunity to head into the open goal.

Zinchenko rounded off the scoring in the 74th minute, meeting a rebound from the crossbar and firing it into the far top corner.

Viera‚Äôs didmissal in the 84th minute came too late. With a man advantage Burnley found the overlap at will, causing problems, but not managing to get the ball in the back of the net.

Onafemi got his first minutes of the season at the end, and Aaron Ramsey returned for his first minutes in a month or more.

Not the drubbing many expected, but with Bournemouth winning at Newcastle, survival is beginning to look a bit more uphill.

Oh, and Arsenal have a drum. It was fucking annoying - we don‚Äôt need a drum. Up the clarets.

‚öΩÔ∏èüìª Discovered the From the Beehole End podcast, which I‚Äôve been listening to all the way South.

Think this is probably my favourite BurnleyFC podcast. Good structured discussion, without unnecessary polish.

Reservioir Levels - STW

Stumbled across this fascinating data from Severn Trent, which is published weekly and shows the water capacity and fill of each of their reservoir groups. Shows that water levels have recovered well from some very critical levels last year.

‚öΩÔ∏èüèüÔ∏èüì∑ Burnley 0 Crystal Palace 2

Nov 4, 2023

Photographs and match review from Burnley v Crystal Palace, 4th November 2023.

After a month on the road, we returned to Turf Moor today, the opponents Crystal Palace. Before that though, I had the small matter of a first visitation of my mother to Burnley. Meeting her in town, we walked back up to Banny’s on Manchester Road for lunch, and for her ride home.

Heading back into Burnley, the drizzle began, and it would continue throughout the afternoon.

This was the best Burnley performance I’ve seen in about a month. The first half in particular there was a bit more directness about our play, a faster turn of the ball, and a wealth of chances, albeit none of them clear cut.

Palace took the lead in the 13th minute, Jordan Beyer slipping in the corner, and outmuscled by Ayew who provided Schlupp with a straightforward tap in.

Palace doubled their lead in injury time at the end of the game, Burnley losing the ball up the pitch while pushing for the equaliser, leaving what was left of the defence exposed.

In between those two points Burnley dominated the game, without ever really creating clear cut chances. Holding over two thirds of the ball, and with 17 attempts on gol to Palace’s 4. Other than a shot straight at James Trafford in the Burnley goal, every Palace shot on target went in.

There’s still a lot to do, but there is at least some hope from this performance of improvement.

One thing that irks me at the Turf is visiting supporters singing “{insert town name} is a shithole, I want to go home”. It’s obviously incredibly disparaging and rude, but the irony of a group of people who live in a concrete monstrosity divided by an open sewer singing it about pretty much anywhere else is not lost. Feel free to stay at home.

Not the result that we wanted, or that I think the performance deserved - but at least green shoots. Zeki Amdouni had a fantastic game and looked involved in most of the good link up play into the box. Luca Koleosho terrorised again on the left wing. Put better final delivery into either of those two, and goals will come.

UTC

Nov 3, 2023

üßóüì∑ Bouldering at Boulder UK, Walton Summit.

Destressing towards the end of one very stressful journey. A couple of weeks off now, gearing up to go again.

Onwards.

‚öΩÔ∏èüèüÔ∏èüì∑ Everton 3 Burnley 0

Nov 1, 2023

Everton v Burnley at Goodison Park, Liverpool on 1 November 2023.

Leaving Burnley at 1620, I caught the supporters club coach at Queensgate. Sadly too late in the day for Milltown Pies to be open.

We arrived outside Stanley Park about an hour before kick-off, picking up a program on the walk into Goodison Park. At ¬£4, this is the most expensive program I‚Äôve bought so far this season.

The ground is a proper old football ground, with old school food kiosks, and a wooden stand. I don‚Äôt think I have ever sat in a stand with a wood floor before. Though I love old grounds, and despise modern bowls, the hospitality in the stadium has not aged well.

To be fair, the food pricing was very sensible. A coffee and a burger set me back around ¬£7.50. However, there were no cheeseburgers left, and the burger that I did obtain was definitely dead, and clearly had been so for a large number of years.

This was the first game at Goodison since the death of Everton‚Äôs chairman, Bill Kenwright. Commemorated with a minutes applause, enthusiastically supported by both sets of fans, with flowers laid on the centre circle.

As for the game, our distribution was clearly much better with Muric in goal. Though I do not really want to join the calls for Trafford to be dropped from goal, his distribution lacks confidence and pace, putting ourselves under pressure in dangerous locations.

As a result Burnley looked much more confident on the ball, dominating possession, but creating few clear chances, and lacking the incisiveness to really threaten goal.

Defensively undone by an unmarked Tarkowski header across goal in the 13th, before Everton were really in the game. Onana scrambled the ball in somehow in the 53rd, with a final goal in injury time.

Burnley had 63% of possession, but never really looked like doing anything with it - it has to be time to start learning and fast.

üïµÔ∏è‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è Kagi - Why Pay for Search?

Oct 26, 2023

Recently I’ve been experimenting with a paid search engine called Kagi, this short article talks about why, how I got one with the trial, and whether I went on to subscribe.

I wrote at the beginning of the year about how I was taking ownership of my web presence through micro.blog. In rebuilding my digital life largely away from traditional social media (I cannot completely avoid the Facewall due to various groups that organise themselves on that platform), I have tried to take a much more privacy conscious approach to building this site.

  • Using privacy conscious tracking through Clicky and more latterly Tinylytics.
  • Avoiding social media embeds that can introduce tracking cookies.
  • Using Loom for recording and hosting new videos rather than YouTube - again avoiding tracking cookies used in the latter (legacy embeds remain).

It occurred to me though, that in continuing to use mainstream search engines, I was denying myself many of the benefits that I had designed into my own web presence for my visitors.

I didn’t go looking for an alternative approach to search. This was not a problem that I really realised that I had, or had put much thought into until I heard @manton talking about Kagi briefly on the Shop Talk Podcast a few weeks ago. At a similar time I also stumbled across Kagi’s Small Web project, that takes me back to the curated internet of old.

So I decided to give the Kagi free trial (100 searches) a go. I didn’t necessarily expect to like it, or think that I needed it, but thought that it would be interesting.

Kagi is lightning fast, but what really struck me straight away is the cleanliness of the search results. No adverts or featured posts, straight into the best search results for whatever the question was. What else would you want from a search engine? In the search below, I’ve asked Kagi why I should pay for search, and sure enough at the top of the page is an extract from Kagi’s help site explaining why you might.

There are a number of advantages to this, not having to wade through a number of irrelevant featured links or ads is just the beginning. I can now dare to search for Z Gauge model train sets, without being confronted by adverts of everything to do with trains on every website for the next month.

There are a few other Kagi projects I need to look into more. I mentioned the Small Web project above, which looks a really interesting project to get involved with, much like the webrings of old (and new, see below!). There is also a browser project called Orion that looks great - though I’m only really interested if it can load passwords from keychain using TouchID. Otherwise I’m sticking to Safari.

So I was sufficiently impressed with my 100 search trial (which lasted longer than I thought it would), to subscribe. For now I’m using the $5/mo which gives 300 searches per month, though I may switch us to the $14/mo Duo Family subscription with unlimited searches at some point in the future.

Anyway hope that you liked the article, and if you did please click below to give kudos, or to join the conversation.

Oct 25, 2023

Race 2 of the Mamiky Series on Rouvy. Tired, and keeping the intensity down for the most part. Average power slightly up, hr significantly down = recovering well.

Oct 22, 2023

Quick Test

‚öΩÔ∏èüì∑ Brentford 3 Burnley 0

Oct 21, 2023

A day out by rail to watch Burnley lose 0 -3 at Brentford in the Gtech / Brentford Community Stadium.

I could not get a place on the supporters coach today, so headed down to London on the train. Despite the disruption from Storm Babet, the trains worked flawlessly in both directions. I even managed to get an earlier train due to the advance cancellation of mine. So strictly the weather made me an hour faster, and the travel was about 3h lighter in each direction for getting train rather than coach.

Once you get into London from the North, the best way to get to Brentford’s stadium is to take the Victoria Line from Euston or Kings Cross to Victoria, and from Victoria to change onto the district to Gunnersbury. Turn left on exiting Gunnersbury, and just keep going, the stadium will appear on your right as you approach Kew Bridge. About an hour altogether.

I had the most intense entry search I’ve had so far. Every single section of my wallet was searched, so in future I’ll take less to football. The program seller is behind the search unit, approaching which felt like a scene from the Shawshank Redemption.

You enter straight into the concourse. Don’t feel like you have to eat from the kiosk here, there is another one upstairs that will be much quieter before the game as few know it is there. Chicken Tikka Pie ¬£5, bag of crisps, bottle of Peroni zero ¬£11.

The away area is rail sit/stand seating, which is really growing on me. The stadium is lovely, but its not found its rhythm yet, and the atmosphere outside the away end felt very subdued, despite the comprehensive home result. At one point we were asking ‘is this a library?’.

The first half was the worst 45 minutes that I’ve seen us play. Out pressed in possession, while allowing space and the reset when not. We give our opponents every advantage when we play like this. Notwithstanding the performance, we very nearly equalised before half time but went in 1 - 0 down. The main highlight of the first half was our new chant, to the tune of ‘one of our own’ - We don’t need a drum, We don’t need a drum, we’re Burnley FC, we don’t need a drum. If you have seen the furore around our advert for a drummer this week, you’ll get it.

The second half was much improved, though we found ourselves in good positions a number of times, nobody wanted to shoot. Koleosho missed an open goal too. Ultimately we were outdone by two unstoppable finished from outside the box - we have to close down with much more urgency than we do today. Trafford made some excellent saves in both halves, but his distribution needs to be faster an more accurate, and he needs to command his box better - he is being bullied by some teams as today.

I expected us to be in the game today. We weren’t. We look a weaker side than the one that started the season, and we do not look like we are learning from our mistakes - I fear a long and difficult season unless there is an imminent uptick.

On the way back, just walk right past Gunnersbury, and turn left onto Chiswick Road, getting back on the District Line at Chiswick Gate. About 1h15 all in.

Eventually made it back into Preston around 9pm.

‚öΩÔ∏èüöùüó∫Ô∏è Wrapping up one of the most miserable and depressing weeks of my entire career with a relaxing day trip out to see a bus stop in Hounslow.

I couldn‚Äôt get on the coach, so train from Preston.

Have been looking forward to seeing this stadium since it opened.

‚öΩÔ∏è Newcastle United 2 Burnley 0

Sep 30, 2023

Photographs from the game today.

Burnley had chances, could and should have scored at either end of the game. Between those two spells, they did not really look in the game.

Authors of their own misfortune again. Though Ramsay appeared to be fouled in the build up to Almiron‚Äôs screamer, not reviewed by VAR - he gave the ball away far too much today.

The second half penalty was a really poor penalty to give away - would have been better keeping tight and forcing a much more difficult cross / shot.

I was disappointed by Burnley‚Äôs performance - we need to put teams under pressure on the ball, and to turn through the phases much faster when we win it back.

The referee had a shocker - absolutely terrible performance. Clearly you are not allowed to actually win the ball away to top 4 sides in the premier league.

Suspect a result on Tuesday away at Luton is key to getting this season going, if we cannot get something there I will begin to worry (Sadly I do not have a ticket).

‚öΩÔ∏èüì∑ Burnley 0 Manchester United 1

Sep 23, 2023

Given Manchester United’s midweek participation in the Champions League, this game took place in the somewhat novel / unusual 8pm slot on Saturday evening.

This was a really strong Burnley performance. Every performance looks much better than the last, the defence looks much more solid, and but for Onana in goal, and his far post, Burnley would have left this game with at least a point.

The stats below speak for themselves, Burnley dominated possession and had an even share of the chances. The irony in losing to a Man Utd long ball should not be lost. ‘Kings of all Europe’ they sang - but not even the best team from Manchester to visit the Turf this year.
